content:
a nice, relaxing smoke
in a new Aston Martin,
and a mad Jag gone bad.

Hello. Now, we got a bit
of a Jaguar theme tonight.

Later on, I'll be looking
at the new XJ,

but look what we've
got in the hangar.
This is the R Coupe.

It's the only one
in the world.

And honestly, have you ever
seen such a beautiful car?
No!

Neither have I. But then, strictly
speaking, it isn't actually a car.

It's a concept. It's a
one-off. It's a flight of fancy.

Jaguar built it to show
the world where they're going.

But we start tonight on our
track with where they came from.

1953, what a top year
for being British.

We climbed Everest,
we broke the 4-minute mile

and we raced this
Jaguar C-Type at Le Mans.

This was the first car
to lap the Le Mans circuit

at an average speed of
more than 100 miles an hour.

But the really interesting
thing is that

the bloke driving
was totally and utterly...
...drunk!
Steady on!

His name
was Duncan Hamilton.

He and co-driver Tony Rolt
qualified for the '53 Le Mans okay,

but were then disqualified
on a technicality.

Hamilton went into town,
he found a local bar,

and got hog-whimperingly
bladdered.

Trouble is, the race organisers then
decided that he could race after all.

So, now we have
the world's lariest car

on the start line of the world's
most gruelling endurance race.

At the wheel is the world's
most plastered racing driver.
And guess what happened.
He won.
This set the tone for Jaguar.

Cars for rotters, for cads,
for absolute bounders.

Do you know, it has to be about
my favourite-ever motor racing story.

- It's fantastic.
- I know what you mean.

I know. Honestly,
my favourite part of it was...

First few pit stops, when
they were refuelling the car,

they were giving the driver, Duncan
Hamilton, they were giving him black coffee.

He was going, "No, no, no,
this is making me all jittery!"

So the second half
they were giving him brandy!
Toughen him up.

Fill the car up with fuel, fill him
up with brandy, send him off again.

And apparently it went on,
because later in the race...

You know, there's no
windscreen on that thing at all.

130 miles an hour,
bird, straight in the face.

- I bet he never noticed! "Whoa, what was that?"
- Nope, carried on.

It was hanging in tatters,
"No, not giving up!"

And the thing is, Jaguar
carried on in that spirit

because then in the '60s,
they had this.

The Mark II. It was glamorous
enough for David Bailey,

and yet genteel enough
for Inspector Morse,

and still fast enough
for London's villains.
Let me show you one feature,

one little detail
that sums up the impact

the Mark II had
when it arrived in 1959.

I'm not talking about
the beautiful grille,

or that long bonnet
or the wire wheels.
It's back here.

It's this badge.
Dunlop disc brakes.

And no, it wasn't just
Jaguar showing off.

You see, these were the same disc brakes
that had brought them victory at Le Mans.

And Jaguar were worried that because
they stopped the Mark II so quickly,

mere mortals might
just pile into the back.
That might sound twee today.

But back in 1959, this
technology was mind-blowing.

Good enough, in fact, to put
the Mark II in a league of its own.

Today, Jaguar may be locked in a
constant struggle with its German rivals.
BMW, Mercedes and Audi,

but let's look at how the
competition stacked up back then.

This is the Mercedes.
A 220 Saloon.
Mmm. Racy!

This is the BMW 2000.
It's getting there,

but power-wise, it's still
very much in short trousers.
And this is the Audi.

They really weren't
trying at all.

They hadn't even
bothered to exist in 1959.

But not only did the Mark II
drive better than everything else,

it also looked better
than everything else.

Quite a tricky double-whammy
to pull off.

Even more so when
you consider that, in 1959,

Jaguar didn't even have
a styling department.

There were no professional style gurus
employed to draw these glorious shapes.

Sir William Lyons,
Jaguar's founder,

would in the day
work in the office,

doing the paperwork,
running the company.

And then over a summer's evening, he'd
work on the prototypes here in his garden,

using the light, just looking to see
how it fell on these gorgeous curves.

And best of all, the head
gardener of the time says that

all the local boys and girls
would line up along that wall

and just peep over
and watch him work.

The 3.8 could hit 60 mph
in 8.5 seconds.

That was faster
than all the Germans,

faster than many of the
purpose-built sports cars of the day.

Faster, even, than some
modern S-Type Jags.

And best of all, it was accessible
because it was so cheap.

In fact, if you take into
consideration just changing fashions,

it wasn't the Jaguar
of its time at all.
It was the Subaru Impreza.

An Aston Martin DB4
came in at 3,200 quid,
with 300 brake horsepower.

But you could have a Mark II
Jaguar 3.8 with 220 brake horsepower
for 1,600 quid.

Some people didn't
even pay that much,

because the Mark II
was the car of choice

for Britain's villainous
getaway drivers.

Roy James, who was the Great
Train Robbers' getaway driver,

was very particular
about his Jag Mark IIs.

He'd always steal a 3.4 rather than a 3.8,
just because he preferred the handling.
Not a lot of people know that.

The Mark II ran for most of the
'60s, but by 1968 it was all over.

And not such
a bad thing, really,

because by then Jaguar had been
swallowed up by British Leyland.

And predictably,
the BL monster

was doing its bit
to screw up everything.

So it had its eight-year run
like most cars,

but for me it remains
the ultimate Jaguar.

It wasn't the first time they'd used
this kind of design or this engine,

but as a package, the Mark II
became the definitive Jaguar saloon.

It might not have the ultimate
knock-out glamour of the E-Type,

but the way we look
at Jaguars today,

as fast, affordable, classy sports
saloons, was defined by this car.

You know, I like
the Mark II, hugely.

But, I didn't really
get into Jaguar

until they launched the
supercharged version in 1990...

- Four.
- Four. That's right.

There's nothing more sinister
than a Black XJR.

- Hannibal Lecter had one.
- And he was sinister.

- And I had one.
- But you're quite sinister.

And the great thing was, is that if
you parked it outside a post office,

while you were away
you always got the sense

that it was in there
robbing the place.
Or eating the postmistress.
But the Lecter...

The Lecter-mobile is gone,
finished. This is the new XJ.

This is the Jaguar saloon
for the 21st century,

and we'll be looking at it
a bit later on.
But now, it's the news.
Right, um...

We start tonight with some Vauxhall news,
which will be of interest to these two chaps

because you've got
an Astra diesel...
What is he doing here?

...and he's got a Vectra,
and not even the new one.

Dearie me. Anyway, we have managed to
secure a photograph of next year's Astra.

- Who would like to see what it looks like?
- Nope. Not really.

- Me.
- You would like to see?
Okay, fair enough.

- No!
- It is nice.

- It's unbelievably nice.
- Terrific.

It'll never look
anything like that, at all.

I thought that, so I rang
Vauxhall up and I said,

"Look, is it really gonna
look like that?"

They said yes. "If it
doesn't, can I eat your dog?"

And he said, "Yeah, okay,
you can eat my dog.

"I promise you, the three-door
Astra, apart from the back end

"which will be a little bit
different, will look like that."

- That's fabulous.
- Absolutely fabulous.

Can I show you something
interesting? Have a look at this, okay?
It's a Ferrari, clearly,

and this stripe is what we're
interested in for the moment.

Reading down
this options list,

how much do you reckon
this costs?

What, to have it
painted on the car?

If you buy just the red car
but you want it as an extra,

- from the options list that I have here...
- £1,000.

- £1,500.
- For a bit of paint?

Shall I tell you?
It's 3,643 quid.

- For a stripe. Seriously.
- Bargain.

Three thousand six?
"Bargain!"

Says the man with
the Astra diesel!

This is the Stradale, which, if
I can explain, is taken from...

They have a championship race
where these compete.

This is the road-going version of
the race car. So it costs £30,000 more.

But it's lighter, it's lower,
they firm up the suspension,

lower the centre of gravity, more
power, about 425 brake horsepower,

and nought to 62
in 4.1 seconds.

It has got paddle shift,
and before you bleat about,

"I don't like
flappy gear boxes,"

it's actually quite good
in that.

I'm sorry.
I'm sorry, everyone.

- Have you driven this car?
- I have.

- And what happened when you drove this car?
- Well, I crashed it.

Tell the nice ladies and
gentlemen about what happened.

Well, I was going
around a corner,

and the next minute I went round
lots and lots of corners very quickly.
I spun it several times.

Actually, this is why it's
called the F360, this model.

'Cause you're driving along and then
you go, "F..." and then you do a 360.

You know, you could be right!
He could be right.
I've got news.

When Rover MG
bought itself from BMW
for a tenner a few years ago,

they made some fairly bold claims
about what they were gonna do.

They said...
I have a list of it here.

They said they were gonna have
a new 45 by 2003,

they said they were gonna have
a V8 engine in the ZT,

they said there was gonna be
an SV supercar.

They said they were gonna
make a space shuttle.
Yeah. Space station.

Yeah, well, they were gonna build a space
shuttle to get to the Rover space station.

A Rover space station would
be fab, actually, wouldn't it?

It would be
dark metallic green...

...and it would have
a grille on

that would sort of appear
every 24 hours as it rotated.

And a really nice clock
somewhere, as well.

We're just thinking of the idea
of Rover launching something.

"T minus six..."
"Did someone say 'tea'?"
So studious!

"I mean, we're going
into space!" "It's 3:30 now,
"we're knocking off, mate!"

- "All ahead!"
- "We'll do the launch in the morning."
Um... Anyway,

no Rover space station, no
supercar that we've been able to see,

no Rover 45s, they've not
annexed China or bought India,

or all the things they said they were
gonna do, but what they have done,

and I've got
a photograph of it here,

is launch some hoops
for the MG. Check it out.

You can now buy
those hoops, which, er,

will cost you £280,
inclusive of VAT,

or if you want them
attached to the car...

Right, reliability studies.
We love these because...

- Oh, God.
- No, we do,

because they tell us not, you know,
which is the fastest nought to 60

but which cars break down
and why.

This is a good one, it's by a company
called, I think, reliabilityindex.com.

- Internet.
- Possibly isn't the best of starts.

But this makes
interesting reading.

Here's their most reliable cars
from their extensive survey work.

Their top ten goes as follows.
Number one, Mazda.

Fair point. Maxdas are
realiable. Anyone got a Mazda?
Yeah. Does it ever break down?

No. No? There you
go. They never do.
MX5 goes forever.

Then in second place, Ford.
Mmm. I suppose nowadays...

- Anyone got a Ford?
- Yes.
Does it ever break down?

- No.
- Yes.
Some do, some don't.

It's the second
most reliable car...

I think this reliability index
gets a bit weak here.

Third most reliable
make of car,
Fiat.

I mean, then it's got, you know,
Honda, Volkswagen, Mercedes,

Toyota, BMW, Volvo,
all the people you'd expect,
but in third place,
Fiat!

- What have they got as being the most unreliable car?
- Well, this is good fun,

because according to them
the second least reliable make,
least reliable make, is.
Subaru!
They don't go wrong!

They're the most reliable
cars imaginable!

I have never in... How long
have I been doing this? 15 years.

I've never had a letter from a Subaru
owner, ever, saying, "My Subaru broke down."
So...

No, no! What was number one? What's
the most unreliable car according to them?

- Toyota? Probably Toyota or Nissan.
- I bet it's some Lexus.

- Jeep.
- Oh, Jeep was one?
Yeah.
Do you want that?
Absolute rubbish!

Well, this is interesting. A brochure about
the opening of a new car park in Leeds.

"Q-Park is not only changing
the way people park

"but also the way
they think about parking.
"Parking... Parking..."

- You're done!
- It gets better.

"Parking provides a vital link
in the mobility chain."
It does! You stop your car...

"It is never an end
in itself."

Well, you don't just go out
to do some parking!
"Put me out there, darling!

- "Have a nice day."
- "Oh, that's better."

I've been invited to the
opening of this car park.

- In Leeds?
- I have to say I'm very disappointed in it.

Because, when I joined
Top Gear, I thought,

"Here we go. French
film festival, Kristen..." No.

I've been invited to the
opening of a car park, and it says,

"Yes, please, I would like to
come to the opening of the car park."

"I will be arriving,
A, by car,
"B, on foot."

So anyway, I rang them up and
I said, "I'd like to come in the car.
"Will there be parking?"

Last week, if you remember, we
launched our search for rubbish cars.

Well, not rubbish cars, cars that
have been ruined, if you remember.

People who've just done
stupid things.

Got a good example that's been sent in, to
give you an idea of what we're looking for.

Started life as a Volvo, okay?
Sensible car.

I've actually seen this
car in real life. Look at that!
Look at that!

He's welded
half a wheelie bin to it.
Where on earth will you get...

When I saw that on the M4,
there was a trail of traffic,

all trying to look,
not just at the car,

but at the idiot
that did that to it.
So, if that's you,

or if you've done anything
like that to your car,

or you know anybody
else who has, please,
drop us a line to,

"I'm a clot and
I've ruined my car."

BBC Top Gear, London,
Wales, W12, Scotland.

Now, in a couple of weeks we're
having a bit of a theme to the show,
which is track days.

So what we're looking for is people who've
been videoing themselves or their friends

going around the track when they made
a complete horlicks of it and crashed.

If you've got any tapes like that,
do send them to us, usual address.
"Top Gear, London W12,

"England, Wales, Scotland, Isle
of Man, Northern Ireland, Berwick."

Now, when I hosted Have I
Got News for You last year,

seven people telephoned the BBC
to say I was a very poor presenter.

When my guest tonight
hosted it,

85 people rang up and said
he was an excellent presenter.

He is the Conservative MP for
Henley, he's editor of The Spectator,

and it seems he's 92 times better
than me at hosting topical news quizzes.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Boris Johnson!

- How are you?
- Nice to see you.
Have a seat.
Thank you.

- This Have I Got News for Youmalarkey...
- Yes.

- ...it is tricky, isn't it?
- Very tricky.

I mean, tricky for me,
at least, anyway.

It was trying to remember which bit
you were supposed to be looking at
at any given time.

I think Angus Deayton
earned his money.

I think they should
bring back Angus.

- Who thinks we should bring back Angus?
- I think bring back...
Yes!

Not bring back hanging,
but bring back Angus.

The thing I've got
to find out, really, is,

most politicians, as far as I can
work out, are pretty incompetent

- and then have a veneer of competence.
- Yes.

You do seem to do it
the other way round.
Yes.

You can't rule out
the possibility

that beneath the elaborately constructed
veneer of, you know, a blithering idiot,

there lurks
a blithering idiot.

- Well, which is it? Are you a blithering idiot?
- No, no, my dear fellow.

What's this about you driving
a tractor through a barn, then?

Yes, it's perfectly true.
This was a long time ago.
I'm... You know...

Have you ever driven
a tractor very fast?
No. Nobody has.

Well, this was actually rather
a fast one, by my standards.

A Massey Ferguson tractor, had a
great many very complicated gears.

And at the crucial moment
I couldn't remember

which gear was the one you use
when you wanted to slow down.

A sort of blankness descended. I went out
through the back of the barn, and, um...

- Through the wall?
- Yeah.

Anyway, it was
all right in the end.

They docked my pay
where I was working, but...

It was perfectly easy
to replace the wall, so...

What were you,
a tractor driver, then?

Part-time, yes.
Part-time tractor driver.
And now you write about cars.
I do, but, you know, I...

Jeremy, I sit at your feet in terms
of writing about cars, anyway,

like Aeschylus feasting from scraps
from the rich banquet of Homer, yeah?

That's the sort of thing that goes
down big on Top Gear, isn't it?

- That's a good thing?
- It is a good thing, yeah.

Because I mean,
I do enjoy...

It's in GQmagazine, your
motoring column. It's very good.

I don't know anything about cars.
As you know... I don't really know.

I shouldn't say that,
actually.

I do know...
I know more than I used to.

Can I just share a little observation
that Boris made about the Maserati here?

"Look how much has been
crammed in.

"The great, big,
fat, long things,

"the vast doodah with the
squiggly bits coming out of the, er...

"Just look
at those sucking..."

Jeremy, I... Do you really know
your stuff, though, about cars?

- Absolutely no idea.
- Yeah.

No, genuinely, I have no idea
how an engine works.

People have sat me down and said,
"No, the petrol goes..." Do you know?
No. Not the faintest.

And then the pistons go up and
down, and somehow you go along.
How does that happen?

He'll know. He's got a beard
and a Rover.

He'll know everything
there is to know about it.

It is a miracle. But
I'm a very keen cyclist.

- Unlike you, I think.
- I loathe cycles. I loathe bikes.

- And you talk on a mobile phone while you're doing it.
- No.
Well, I do. I do, yes.

When I said "No," I wanted to
make a point about

my willingness to learn
and to reform,

because it's perfectly true that I did
once talk on a mobile phone whilst cycling.

And, actually, why shouldn't you
be able to talk on a mobile phone?

- Because you can't reach the brakes!
- You can with one hand.

I have this exact
same thing...

Are you saying that people with one
arm shouldn't be allowed to ride a bicycle?
Are you?

Because I put it to you
that that is discriminatory.

Yes, people with one arm should not be
allowed to ride a bicycle on the basis that...

- What do you mean?
- ...no one should be allowed to ride a bicycle.

- Ah!
- They take up too much space on the road,

and they don't pay
to be there.

Well, I think bicycles are
absolutely wonderful.

You wouldn't park
in a cycle lane, would you?

- Park in one?
- You wouldn't park in one...

No, but I do drive in them
fairly regularly.

- You drive in cycle lanes?
- Yeah, and bus lanes.

- I think the bus lane is a very good idea.
- For you?

Yeah, because you think,
"Everyone's not in this,

"fantastic. I'm late,
I'll just zoom up it."

- Are you allowed to say that on telly?
- I just did.
Whether it gets in is their...

I defy the makers of Top Gear to
keep that admission in the final edit.

- Well, now...
- I think that's a bit of a challenge.

Until Sunday night,
we're not going to know

- whether it makes it into the final edit or not.
- That's outrageous.

What, that I drive in bus lanes?
Who here drives in bus lanes?
One... Two.

Exactly. There's only three of us who drive
in bus lanes. They're empty for our use.
So what's it like on the road?

Are you the kind of guy that has
your car towed away the whole time?

Uh, it has been towed away now and
then, yeah. I wouldn't hide it from you.

I have to say, the last time it happened
it was in defiance of every by-law.
It was...

My car was legally parked.
There was absolutely no question.

And I had the testimony of two traffic
wardens that it was legally parked

- in a residents' permit parking bay.
- Mmm-hmm.

But the point I want to make is that
once your car... Do you know this?

Once your car is
one inch off the ground,

once it's in that dreadful
hammock, and they've got it,

it is no longer yours. You have no
rights over that vehicle any more.

There's nothing you can say
to the chap, the tower,

- to stop him.
- I have a theory on that.

- Who'd like to hear my theory on that?
- Yeah.

I think if you leapt onto the
bonnet as it was dangling around...

And you've got one wheel
down onto the tarmac?
No, health and...

There's no way in hell that a health
and safety law is gonna allow you to be...

They'll have to put it back
down again. I'm sure of that.

Now, of course,
you're here, really,

to find out just how good
a driver you are, I guess.

Yes, I have an idea
about that.

- Really?
- I think I'm extremely bad.
Really? "Extremely bad"!

- Who'd like to see Boris's lap?
- Yes!
Here we go.
Well, that was a start.

It's already been
made clear to me by my coach,
a chap called Stig,

I'm the worst driver
he's ever met.

I got to aim for the apex.
Aim for the apex!

Who hooted at me? Someone

Well, there we are!
Across the line!

Don't feel bad about the off-road

No, it was fine, it was fine.
Very good car, the Neon.

It is a very good car.
Very reasonably priced.

I think you can buy them now

Or you gonna be more a

You know,
I've no idea.

He's only 13 seconds

13 seconds on that track is

Anyway, I have your time here.

56 seconds, everybody!

He's faster

Could be worse.

Ladies and gentlemen,
Boris Johnson!
Right!
The new Jaguar XJ.

But in fact it's bigger,

Things like room in the back

You all right there?
Comfortable? Good.

Actually, I've got to say,

for some reason,

but apparently there

You also get,
for the first time in an XJ,

a proper-sized boot

- Yeah, very.

But despite all of this,
despite being bigger,

it manages to be a fifth of a

And that's because the new one
is made of aluminium.

And a lighter car is gonna be nimbler,
it's gonna be faster, more economical,

and of course,
kinder to the environment.

The thing is, though, the old XJ,
the one I couldn't fit in the boot of,

that was made of lead and rock

So it was like
a big velvet glove.

Pick you up at the end
of a hard day at work

and then gently
deposit you at home.

Now this one, lighter, more
high-tech. What worries me

is that some of the
Jaguariness will have been lost.

So, to find out,
I designed a cunning test.

Because Jaguars are supposed
to ease the burden of travel,

I thought I'd see how far
I could go in the new one

before I got bored and tired
and irritable.

There are so many things that
usually annoy me on a motorway,

like people in Mondeos,
registration number M134 LWR,

who sit in the middle lane
for no reason.
But there is fun stuff, too.

Well, here we are in Birmingham.
And I must say, it's very nice of Bosch

to advertise the programme
like that.

So far as the car's concerned,
however, I've nothing to report.
It's fine.
Mmm, the M6. All solid.

If I were in a Mercedes,
I'd be,

"Come on! Come on, everybody!
Get out of the way!"
But in the Jag, I'm relaxed.

So they have an accident
in road works

and they're not even
doing any road works.

And ordinarily, that would
annoy me, but I'm not bothered.

Eventually I broke free from the
obstacle course that is Birmingham

and found the supercharged Jag
has lost none of its superchargedness.

The extraordinary thing
about this is

is that whether you're going
50 or 70,

or even a little bit more
than that,

there's no difference in how it
feels or sounds. It's amazing!
This is Staffordshire now,

voted recently in a survey
by Country Life Magazine

as the worst county
in all of England.

But they won't have looked
